title: 109_hr2936
content: The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to cover second opinions under the Public Health Service Act. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide or authorize second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals when requested by participants, beneficiaries, or enrollees questioning surgical procedures, diagnoses, or unclear clinical indications. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to provide second opinions by qualified healthcare professionals when clinical indications are unclear, treatment is not improving, or there are concerns about the diagnosis or plan of care. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates that group health plans must offer second opinions from appropriately qualified healthcare professionals when there are serious concerns about the diagnosis or plan of care. Authorization or denial of the second opinion request must be provided promptly, especially in cases where the individual's health is at imminent risk. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to offer timely second opinions for participants facing serious health threats. Plans must establish response timelines for emergency cases within 90 days of enactment, with updates within 30 days of any changes. Liability for costs is limited for group health plans and insurance issuers. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to provide timely second opinions for urgent care needs. Participants can request a second opinion within 90 days of enactment, with updates every 30 days. Liability for costs is limited for group health plans and insurance issuers. Second opinions can be obtained from a qualified health care professional of the individual's choice within the same physician organization for primary care requests, and from any provider of the individual's choice for specialist care. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to offer timely second opinions for urgent care needs. Participants can request a second opinion within 90 days, with updates every 30 days. Second opinions for primary care must be from a qualified health care professional within the same physician organization, while specialist care can be from any provider of the individual's choice within the network. If no provider meets the required standard, the plan must authorize a second opinion from an outside health professional. If no participating provider meets the required standard, the plan must authorize a second opinion from an outside health professional. The second opinion health professional must provide a consultation report with recommended procedures or tests. The plan can also authorize additional medical opinions based on its independent determination. The plan or issuer must notify the participant, beneficiary, or enrollee in writing if a request for a second opinion is denied, providing reasons for the denial and information on filing a grievance. Services must be obtained from participating providers unless authorized otherwise by the plan or issuer. Referrals may be limited to the plan's network of providers. The participant, beneficiary, or enrollee must use services from a provider in the plan's network. Referrals may be restricted to network providers. Exemption for preferred provider contracts allowing second opinions. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements. Section 2723(c) of the Act is amended. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 requires compliance with notice requirements for group health plans. Section 2723(c) of the Act is amended to include sections 2704 and 2707. "Section 714 addresses coverage of second opinions." Section 714 of the Act addresses coverage of second opinions, while section 2707 applies to group health plans and insurance coverage. The requirement of section 2707 is considered a material modification in plan terms, with notice to be provided within 60 days of the requirement applying. Additionally, sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act are amended to include section 714. Section 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act are amended to include section 714 in the table of contents. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include coverage of second opinions under section 9813. Additionally, the Public Health Service Act is amended to include coverage of second opinions under section 2753. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements. Amendments are made to section 2762(b)(2) of the Act. Effective dates for group health plans and individual health insurance coverage are specified. Effective dates for group health plans and individual health insurance coverage are specified. Group health plans are affected for plan years starting on or after January 1, 2006, while individual health insurance coverage is impacted on or after that date. There is an exception for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by subsection (a) do not apply to plan years before the later of the termination of collective bargaining agreements or January 1, 2006. Plan amendments made to conform to requirements added by subsection (a) do not terminate collective bargaining agreements. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services will coordinate administration through an interagency memorandum of understanding. Services will ensure that regulations, rulings, and interpretations issued by multiple Secretaries are administered consistently and that enforcement policies are coordinated to avoid duplication of efforts and prioritize enforcement.
